elements.content: The removal of acetylene from the industrial feed gas to purify the ethylene is an important and challenging issue. The adsorption-based separation is a more environmentally friendly and cost-effective method compared to the current removal approaches such as partial hydrogenation and solvent extraction, while facing the challenge of developing materials with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and C2H2 capacity. Herein, by expanding mixed-metal organic frameworks (M’MOFs) structure with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, we report a pillar-layered MOF, {[Cd5(MPCZ)2(BDC)3(NO3)2(H2O)4]·G} n (MECS-5), which not only inherits the sieving effects of M’MOF series but also develops its own characteristicthe 2D layer with expanding space and the plane pore-partition group to “cover” it. MECS-5 shows higher ideal adsorption solution theory C2H2/C2H4 selectivity than the most reported MOFs, especially more than 5 times higher than MOF-74 series while displaying great enhancement in the C2H2 capacity, more than 2 times higher compared to the M’MOF. The column breakthrough experiment further proves the possibility of MECS-5a for real industrial ethylene purification.
elements.clean_text: The removal of acetylene from the industrial feed gas to purify the ethylene is an important and challenging issue. The adsorption-based separation is a more environmentally friendly and cost-effective method compared to the current removal approaches such as partial hydrogenation and solvent extraction, while facing the challenge of developing materials with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and C2H2 capacity. Herein, by expanding mixed-metal organic frameworks (M'MOFs) structure with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, we report a pillar-layered MOF, {[Cd5(MPCZ)2(BDC)3(NO3)2(H2O)4]⋅G} n  (MECS-5), which not only inherits the sieving effects of M'MOF series but also develops its own characteristicthe 2D layer with expanding space and the plane pore-partition group to "cover" it. MECS-5 shows higher ideal adsorption solution theory C2H2/C2H4 selectivity than the most reported MOFs, especially more than 5 times higher than MOF-74 series while displaying great enhancement in the C2H2 capacity, more than 2 times higher compared to the M'MOF. The column breakthrough experiment further proves the possibility of MECS-5a for real industrial ethylene purification.

elements.content: Ethylene is one of the most important chemical raw materials, and polymer products based on ethylene have been widely used in people’s daily lives. Because of its industrial production method of steam cracking of hydrocarbons, however, there is usually about 1% of acetylene residue in the ethylene feed gas, and this acetylene residue will cause great trouble with the next polymerization. So it is very necessary to purify the ethylene feed gas and the concentration of the acetylene should be reduced to an acceptable level. The current approaches for the C2H2/C2H4 separation in the petrochemical industry are partial hydrogenation and solvent extraction. Unfortunately, both of them are high in cost and energy consumption. The former process needs a noble metal catalyst and usually loss of olefin, while the latter wastes lots of solvent. Therefore, developing cost-effective and environmentally friendly separation method of acetylene and ethylene is in urgent need. Using porous materials to selectively separate the gas at the normal pressure and temperature is an attractive and challenging method. The key issue is to develop porous materials which have high selectivity and adsorption capacity for acetylene at the same time. Unfortunately, traditional porous materials, such as active carbon and zeolites, present poor performance in the C2H2/C2H4 separation due to the similarity of the two substances in the molecular dynamic radius.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Ethylene is one of the most important chemical raw materials, and polymer products based on ethylene have been widely used in people's daily lives. Because of its industrial production method of steam cracking of hydrocarbons, however, there is usually about 1% of acetylene residue in the ethylene feed gas, and this acetylene residue will cause great trouble with the next polymerization. So it is very necessary to purify the ethylene feed gas and the concentration of the acetylene should be reduced to an acceptable level. The current approaches for the C2H2/C2H4 separation in the petrochemical industry are partial hydrogenation and solvent extraction. Unfortunately, both of them are high in cost and energy consumption. The former process needs a noble metal catalyst and usually loss of olefin, while the latter wastes lots of solvent. Therefore, developing cost-effective and environmentally friendly separation method of acetylene and ethylene is in urgent need. Using porous materials to selectively separate the gas at the normal pressure and temperature is an attractive and challenging method. The key issue is to develop porous materials which have high selectivity and adsorption capacity for acetylene at the same time. Unfortunately, traditional porous materials, such as active carbon and zeolites, present poor performance in the C2H2/C2H4 separation due to the similarity of the two substances in the molecular dynamic radius.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks, constructed by metal ions and organic ligands, not only have high surface area but also provide the platform for scientists to design materials with particular size and chemical environments at the molecular level, which create more of a possibility to develop efficient separation materials for C2H2/C2H4. Compared with the MOFs used for other gas separations such as CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2, until now there are only a few reported MOFs used for the C2H2/C2H4 separation, for example, the series MOF-74, M’MOF, SIXSIF, NOTT-300, and UTSA. Among them, the M’MOF series possesses good selectivity for C2H2/C2H4 because of the sieving effect but with low capacity, while the MOF-74 series is the opposite; it has low selectivity but high capacity. Only the SIXSIF series recently reported by Chen’s group shows excellent C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and high C2H2 uptake (). It is a challenge and needs careful and diligent thinking for the design and syntheses of the MOFs with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and C2H2 uptake.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks, constructed by metal ions and organic ligands, not only have high surface area but also provide the platform for scientists to design materials with particular size and chemical environments at the molecular level, which create more of a possibility to develop efficient separation materials for C2H2/C2H4. Compared with the MOFs used for other gas separations such as CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2, until now there are only a few reported MOFs used for the C2H2/C2H4 separation, for example, the series MOF-74, M'MOF, SIXSIF, NOTT-300, and UTSA. Among them, the M'MOF series possesses good selectivity for C2H2/C2H4 because of the sieving effect but with low capacity, while the MOF-74 series is the opposite; it has low selectivity but high capacity. Only the SIXSIF series recently reported by Chen's group shows excellent C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and high C2H2 uptake (). It is a challenge and needs careful and diligent thinking for the design and syntheses of the MOFs with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and C2H2 uptake.

<title>Imitating from M’MOF To Design
the Structure of MOF with High C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub>/C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub> Selectivity and C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> Uptake</title>
</caption>

elements.clean_text: 1  Imitating from M'MOF To Design the Structure of MOF with High C2H2/C2H4 Selectivity and C2H2 Uptake

elements.content: Imitating reported MOFs with good selectivity or capacity and elaborately adjusting their structures may be an efficient way for developing suitable C2H2/C2H4 separation materials. We noticed that the most reported MOFs usually have high C2H2 uptake but low selectivity, while MOFs with high selectivity are rare. It seems that it is more difficult to improve the selectivity than the capacity. The M’MOF series featured with the pillar-layered structure is experimentally proven to be the kind of structure that is easy to control, while their ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) selectivity for C2H2/C2H4 can easily reach a high level in the reported MOFs (). Besides, we noticed that the pores in the two-dimensional framework constructed by the ligand H2BDC and Cd­(II) ions can exist in two kinds of forms: one is the small pores of triangle shape surrounded with three walls of terephthalic acids; another is the larger pore of quadrangle shape surrounded with four walls (). The 2D layers of the reported M’MOF series adopted the former, which limits the adsorption capacity. It inspired us to think that if the 2D layers adopt the larger pore form while maintaining the framework of M’MOF series, the C2H2 adsorption capacity may be improved while still keeping the high selectivity. Moreover, the reported pore space partition is one good strategy to divide the open channel into a smaller space for enhancing the interaction between the MOFs and gas which can be taken into account when designing the MOFs because the pores of the reported pillar-layered MOFs are usually open channels which is not conducive to effectively capture the target gas in the pores.
elements.clean_text: Imitating reported MOFs with good selectivity or capacity and elaborately adjusting their structures may be an efficient way for developing suitable C2H2/C2H4 separation materials. We noticed that the most reported MOFs usually have high C2H2 uptake but low selectivity, while MOFs with high selectivity are rare. It seems that it is more difficult to improve the selectivity than the capacity. The M'MOF series featured with the pillar-layered structure is experimentally proven to be the kind of structure that is easy to control, while their ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) selectivity for C2H2/C2H4 can easily reach a high level in the reported MOFs (). Besides, we noticed that the pores in the two-dimensional framework constructed by the ligand H2BDC and Cd(II) ions can exist in two kinds of forms: one is the small pores of triangle shape surrounded with three walls of terephthalic acids; another is the larger pore of quadrangle shape surrounded with four walls (). The 2D layers of the reported M'MOF series adopted the former, which limits the adsorption capacity. It inspired us to think that if the 2D layers adopt the larger pore form while maintaining the framework of M'MOF series, the C2H2 adsorption capacity may be improved while still keeping the high selectivity. Moreover, the reported pore space partition is one good strategy to divide the open channel into a smaller space for enhancing the interaction between the MOFs and gas which can be taken into account when designing the MOFs because the pores of the reported pillar-layered MOFs are usually open channels which is not conducive to effectively capture the target gas in the pores.

elements.content: Taking all the above into account, herein by imitating from the M’MOF series, we report a pillar-layered MOF, MECS-5, constructed by the terephthalic acid and Schiff base HMPCZ liangd (HMPCZ = 2-hydroxy-3-methoxy-benzaldehyde-pyridin-3-ylcarbonylhydrazone) with Cd­(II) ions (). Compared with M’MOF series, the layers of MECS-5 possess expanding pores, which are 2 × 2 grid pores (). In particular, the planar binuclear Cd­(II) building block units constructed by the HMPCZ and the Cd­(II) ions not only act as the pillars connecting the 2D layer to the 3D MOF but also act as the “cap” cover of the 2 × 2 grid pores in the 2D layer and divide the 1-D channel space into smaller segments (). The well-designed MECS-5 finally combines the sieving effects and pore space partition, making it present high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and C2H2 adsorption capacity ().
elements.clean_text: Taking all the above into account, herein by imitating from the M'MOF series, we report a pillar-layered MOF, MECS-5, constructed by the terephthalic acid and Schiff base HMPCZ liangd (HMPCZ = 2-hydroxy-3-methoxy-benzaldehyde-pyridin-3-ylcarbonylhydrazone) with Cd(II) ions (). Compared with M'MOF series, the layers of MECS-5 possess expanding pores, which are 2 × 2 grid pores (). In particular, the planar binuclear Cd(II) building block units constructed by the HMPCZ and the Cd(II) ions not only act as the pillars connecting the 2D layer to the 3D MOF but also act as the "cap" cover of the 2 × 2 grid pores in the 2D layer and divide the 1-D channel space into smaller segments (). The well-designed MECS-5 finally combines the sieving effects and pore space partition, making it present high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and C2H2 adsorption capacity ().

elements.content: Except for the ligand HMPCZ, all the reagents and solvents were purchased. The ligand HMPCZ was synthesized according to ref . Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer was used to collect the infrared spectra from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch Thermo Microbalance TG 209 F3 Tarsus from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under flowing nitrogen. The X-ray powder diffraction patterns were measured on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA with a Cu target tube and a graphite monochromator.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

Except for the ligand HMPCZ, all the reagents and solvents were purchased. The ligand HMPCZ was synthesized according to ref . Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer was used to collect the infrared spectra from KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch Thermo Microbalance TG 209 F3 Tarsus from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under flowing nitrogen. The X-ray powder diffraction patterns were measured on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA with a Cu target tube and a graphite monochromator.

elements.content: Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (123.2 mg, 0.4 mmol), HMPCZ (54.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), and H2BDC (80.2 mg, 0.3 mmol) were dissolved in the mixture of dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a glass bottle with a cover and then heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, yellow block-shaped crystals of MECS-5 were obtained and washed with DMF. Yield: 46% (based on the ligand). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3451 (br), 2930 (m), 2859 (w), 1613 (w), 1574 (w), 1507 (m), 1469 (m), 1375 (m), 1315 (m), 1262 (m), 1181 (w), 1107 (s), 1081 (s), 982 (m), 826 (m), 771 (m), 739 (w), 620 (m), 458 (w).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Cd5(MPCZ)2(BDC)3(NO3)2(H2O)4]⋅G} n  (MECS-5)

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (123.2 mg, 0.4 mmol), HMPCZ (54.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), and H2BDC (80.2 mg, 0.3 mmol) were dissolved in the mixture of dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a glass bottle with a cover and then heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, yellow block-shaped crystals of MECS-5 were obtained and washed with DMF. Yield: 46% (based on the ligand). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3451 (br), 2930 (m), 2859 (w), 1613 (w), 1574 (w), 1507 (m), 1469 (m), 1375 (m), 1315 (m), 1262 (m), 1181 (w), 1107 (s), 1081 (s), 982 (m), 826 (m), 771 (m), 739 (w), 620 (m), 458 (w).

elements.content: Data collections were performed at 298 K on a Bruker Smart Apex II diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for MECS-5. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. Structural solutions and full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 were performed with the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 program packages, respectively. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The solvent molecules in the compound are highly disordered. The SQUEEZE option in PLATON was used to remove the disordered solvent molecules. The hydrogen atoms on organic motives were placed at calculated position and the coordinated water hydrogen atoms were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. All hydrogen atoms of the coordinated solvent water molecules have not been added. Details of the crystal parameters, data collections, and refinements for complexes MECS-5 are summarized in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are shown in Table S2. Further details are provided in the Supporting Information. The CCDC number for compound MECS-5 is 1536047.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Refinement

Data collections were performed at 298 K on a Bruker Smart Apex II diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for MECS-5. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. Structural solutions and full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 were performed with the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 program packages, respectively. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The solvent molecules in the compound are highly disordered. The SQUEEZE option in PLATON was used to remove the disordered solvent molecules. The hydrogen atoms on organic motives were placed at calculated position and the coordinated water hydrogen atoms were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. All hydrogen atoms of the coordinated solvent water molecules have not been added. Details of the crystal parameters, data collections, and refinements for complexes MECS-5 are summarized in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are shown in Table S2. Further details are provided in the Supporting Information. The CCDC number for compound MECS-5 is 1536047.

elements.content: The N2, C2H2, and C2H4 sorption measurements were performed on automatic volumetric adsorption equipment (Belsorp-max). Before gas adsorption measurements, the samples were immersed in MeOH for exchanging the guest at least five times, then filtered, and dried at room temperature. Then the samples were activated by heating at 80 °C under vacuum conditions for 24 h. A sample of activated MECS-5a (70–100 mg) was used for the sorption measurement and was maintained at 77 K with liquid nitrogen, at 273 K with an ice–water bath, and at 298 K with the water bath.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Experiments

The N2, C2H2, and C2H4 sorption measurements were performed on automatic volumetric adsorption equipment (Belsorp-max). Before gas adsorption measurements, the samples were immersed in MeOH for exchanging the guest at least five times, then filtered, and dried at room temperature. Then the samples were activated by heating at 80 °C under vacuum conditions for 24 h. A sample of activated MECS-5a (70-100 mg) was used for the sorption measurement and was maintained at 77 K with liquid nitrogen, at 273 K with an ice-water bath, and at 298 K with the water bath.

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of HMPCZ, H2BDC, and Cd­(NO3)2 in the mixture of the H2O and DMF solvent at 100 °C for 3 days yielded the yellow crystals. The X-ray single-crystal diffraction experiment showed that the yellow crystal crystallized in the monoclinic crystal system, I 2/a space group and formulated as {[Cd5(MPCZ)2(BDC)3(NO3)2-(H2O)4]·G} n (MECS-5). As shown in Figure S1a, the asymmetric unit of MECS-5 contains one deprotonated Schiff base ligand, MPCZ–, one and a half deprotonated terephthalic acid, BDC2–, one nitrate ion, two and a half Cd­(II) ions, and three coordinated solvent molecules. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structure Characterization

The solvothermal reaction of HMPCZ, H2BDC, and Cd(NO3)2 in the mixture of the H2O and DMF solvent at 100 °C for 3 days yielded the yellow crystals. The X-ray single-crystal diffraction experiment showed that the yellow crystal crystallized in the monoclinic crystal system, I 2/a space group and formulated as {[Cd5(MPCZ)2(BDC)3(NO3)2-(H2O)4]⋅G} n  (MECS-5). As shown in Figure S1a, the asymmetric unit of MECS-5 contains one deprotonated Schiff base ligand, MPCZ-, one and a half deprotonated terephthalic acid, BDC2-, one nitrate ion, two and a half Cd(II) ions, and three coordinated solvent molecules. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S2.

elements.content: The trinuclear Cd­(II) building unit, Cd3(O2CR)6, can be generated by the Cd1, Cd2, Cd1#1 (#1: 0.5 – x, y, −z) and the BDC2– through the symmetrical operation (Figure S1b) which is similar to the reported Cd3(O2CR)6. In the trinuclear Cd­(II) building unit, the two Cd2 in the end are seven-coordinated to one oxygen atom from one K 1-coordinated carboxylate, two oxygen atoms from two K 2-coordinated carboxylates, one oxygen atom from the coordinated H2O molecules, and one nitrogen atom from the pyridine nitrogen atom of HMPCZ in the axial position of the trinuclear Cd­(II) building unit. The central Cd1 atom is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms from six carboxylates forming the dodecahedron coordination geometry. Then the Cd3(O2CR)6 units are linked to each other through the BDC2– to form the 2D layer with a certain thickness in the ab plane ( and Figure S2). As shown in , in the 2D layer, taking the BDC2– as the wall and the Cd3(O2CR)6 units as the pillar, the 2 × 2 grid cavity can be seen with the sizes of 9.403 × 11.408 × 6.801 Å. Thus, compared to the M’MOF series, MECS-5 possesses the expanding pore space in the 2D layer for accommodating more gas molecules. What is more, the coordinated H2O molecules directly face the cavity, which can be removed and provide open Cd­(II) sites.
elements.clean_text: The trinuclear Cd(II) building unit, Cd3(O2CR)6, can be generated by the Cd1, Cd2, Cd1#1 (#1: 0.5 - x, y, -z) and the BDC2- through the symmetrical operation (Figure S1b) which is similar to the reported Cd3(O2CR)6. In the trinuclear Cd(II) building unit, the two Cd2 in the end are seven-coordinated to one oxygen atom from one K 1-coordinated carboxylate, two oxygen atoms from two K 2-coordinated carboxylates, one oxygen atom from the coordinated H2O molecules, and one nitrogen atom from the pyridine nitrogen atom of HMPCZ in the axial position of the trinuclear Cd(II) building unit. The central Cd1 atom is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms from six carboxylates forming the dodecahedron coordination geometry. Then the Cd3(O2CR)6 units are linked to each other through the BDC2- to form the 2D layer with a certain thickness in the ab plane ( and Figure S2). As shown in , in the 2D layer, taking the BDC2- as the wall and the Cd3(O2CR)6 units as the pillar, the 2 × 2 grid cavity can be seen with the sizes of 9.403 × 11.408 × 6.801 Å. Thus, compared to the M'MOF series, MECS-5 possesses the expanding pore space in the 2D layer for accommodating more gas molecules. What is more, the coordinated H2O molecules directly face the cavity, which can be removed and provide open Cd(II) sites.

elements.content: Pillar-layered structure of MECS-5 (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; Cd, pink; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  Pillar-layered structure of MECS-5 (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; Cd, pink; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: At the same time, in MECS-5, two deprotonated ligand MPCZ– as well as two Cd­(II) ions assembled into the planar binuclear Cd­(II) building unit, [Cd2(MPCZ)2(NO3)2(H2O)2]. In the binuclear Cd­(II) building unit, Cd­(II) is seven-coordinated to four oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from two MPCZ– to form the plane, leaving two oxygen atoms respectively from one nitrate ion and one-coordinated H2O molecule in the axial of the plane (Figure S3). The pyridine groups in the planar binuclear Cd­(II) building unit make the unit equivalent to the classical pillar, 4,4′-bipyridine, connecting the 2D layers to construct the 3D pillar-layered MOF ( and Figure S4). However, compared to the simple 4,4′-bipyridine, the binuclear Cd­(II) unit contains the open Cd­(II) sites generated by removing the coordinated H2O molecules. Thanks to the planarity of the binuclear Cd­(II) unit and its dihedral angle of 53.431° between the dinuclear plane and the terminal pyridyl group, in MECS-5 the binuclear Cd­(II) unit is also treated as the “cap” to cover the 2 × 2 grid pores in the 2D layer and assume the role of pore-partition group to divide the channel space into the smaller segments ().
elements.clean_text: At the same time, in MECS-5, two deprotonated ligand MPCZ- as well as two Cd(II) ions assembled into the planar binuclear Cd(II) building unit, [Cd2(MPCZ)2(NO3)2(H2O)2]. In the binuclear Cd(II) building unit, Cd(II) is seven-coordinated to four oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from two MPCZ- to form the plane, leaving two oxygen atoms respectively from one nitrate ion and one-coordinated H2O molecule in the axial of the plane (Figure S3). The pyridine groups in the planar binuclear Cd(II) building unit make the unit equivalent to the classical pillar, 4,4'-bipyridine, connecting the 2D layers to construct the 3D pillar-layered MOF ( and Figure S4). However, compared to the simple 4,4'-bipyridine, the binuclear Cd(II) unit contains the open Cd(II) sites generated by removing the coordinated H2O molecules. Thanks to the planarity of the binuclear Cd(II) unit and its dihedral angle of 53.431° between the dinuclear plane and the terminal pyridyl group, in MECS-5 the binuclear Cd(II) unit is also treated as the "cap" to cover the 2 × 2 grid pores in the 2D layer and assume the role of pore-partition group to divide the channel space into the smaller segments ().

elements.content: To remove the solvents in MECS-5, the as-synthesized samples were immersed in MeOH for exchanging the solvent guest at least five times and then filtered. Then the samples were heated at 80 °C under vacuum conditions for 24 h to obtain the activated MECS-5a. The XRD and TGA results show that the solvent molecules were completely removed in the activated MECS-5a while maintaining the structure (). The N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K shows a typical type-I isotherm, indicating the microporosity of MECS-5a with the Langmuir area of MECS-5a calculated to be 964 m2 g–1 (a) which is larger than the M’MOF series, reflecting the expanding space of the MECS-5a.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Separation Performance and Mechanism

To remove the solvents in MECS-5, the as-synthesized samples were immersed in MeOH for exchanging the solvent guest at least five times and then filtered. Then the samples were heated at 80 °C under vacuum conditions for 24 h to obtain the activated MECS-5a. The XRD and TGA results show that the solvent molecules were completely removed in the activated MECS-5a while maintaining the structure (). The N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K shows a typical type-I isotherm, indicating the microporosity of MECS-5a with the Langmuir area of MECS-5a calculated to be 964 m2 g-1 (a) which is larger than the M'MOF series, reflecting the expanding space of the MECS-5a.

elements.content: (a) PXRD pattern of MECS-5, (b) TGA curves of MECS-5, MECS-5 soaked in MeOH, and the activated MECS-5a.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) PXRD pattern of MECS-5, (b) TGA curves of MECS-5, MECS-5 soaked in MeOH, and the activated MECS-5a.

elements.content: (a) Adsorption isotherm of MECS-5a for N2 at 77 K; (b) adsorption isotherms of MECS-5a for C2H2 and C2H4 at 273 and 298 K; (c) C2H2/C2H4 selectivity for MECS-5a at 298 K calculated by the IAST method in C2H2/C2H4 (1/99) binary mixtures; (d) Q st of MECS-5a for C2H2 and C2H4.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Adsorption isotherm of MECS-5a for N2 at 77 K; (b) adsorption isotherms of MECS-5a for C2H2 and C2H4 at 273 and 298 K; (c) C2H2/C2H4 selectivity for MECS-5a at 298 K calculated by the IAST method in C2H2/C2H4 (1/99) binary mixtures; (d) Q st of MECS-5a for C2H2 and C2H4.

elements.content: As shown in b, the adsorption isotherms of C2H2 and C2H4 at 273 and 298 K indicate that compound MECS-5a has obviously different adsorption amounts for C2H2 and C2H4. The uptake amounts of MECS-5a for C2H2 are 125.5 cm3·g–1 (3.85 mmol·g–1) at 273 K and 1 bar and 86.2 cm3·g–1 (2.74 mmol·g–1) at 298 K and 1 bar. For C2H4, the uptake amounts are quite small, only 34.6 cm3·g–1 (1.54 mmol·g–1) at 273 K and 25.5 cm3·g–1 (1.14 mmol·g–1) at 298 K, respectively. Compared with the M’MOF series, the adsorption amount of MECS-5a for C2H2 is improved (Table S3), which could be attributed to the larger specific surface area coming from the expanding space in the 2D layer and the smaller segments divided by the dinuclear Cd­(II) plane pore-partition group. Though the C2H2 uptake amount of MECS-5a is smaller than the other MOFs, such as MOF-74 and NOTT-100a, the C2H4 uptake amount of MECS-5a is far smaller which reveals the better selectivity of MECS-5a.
elements.clean_text: As shown in b, the adsorption isotherms of C2H2 and C2H4 at 273 and 298 K indicate that compound MECS-5a has obviously different adsorption amounts for C2H2 and C2H4. The uptake amounts of MECS-5a for C2H2 are 125.5 cm3⋅g-1 (3.85 mmol⋅g-1) at 273 K and 1 bar and 86.2 cm3⋅g-1 (2.74 mmol⋅g-1) at 298 K and 1 bar. For C2H4, the uptake amounts are quite small, only 34.6 cm3⋅g-1 (1.54 mmol⋅g-1) at 273 K and 25.5 cm3⋅g-1 (1.14 mmol⋅g-1) at 298 K, respectively. Compared with the M'MOF series, the adsorption amount of MECS-5a for C2H2 is improved (Table S3), which could be attributed to the larger specific surface area coming from the expanding space in the 2D layer and the smaller segments divided by the dinuclear Cd(II) plane pore-partition group. Though the C2H2 uptake amount of MECS-5a is smaller than the other MOFs, such as MOF-74 and NOTT-100a, the C2H4 uptake amount of MECS-5a is far smaller which reveals the better selectivity of MECS-5a.

elements.content: To investigate the C2H2 selectivity, the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) base method (c) was used to calculated the separation selectivity of C2H2 versus C2H4 in the binary C2H2/C2H4 mixtures containing 1% C2H2 to simulate the typical industrial mixture. As shown in c, the selectivity of C2H2/C2H4 displayed the decreasing trend from 17.5 to 12.6 in the range of 0–100 KPa. At 100 KPa and 298 K, the selectivity of compound MECS-5a is higher than most reported MOFs, such as the MOF-74 series, NOTT-300 (∼5.5), and UTSA-100a (10.72), and similar to M’MOF-4a (14.4) (Table S3). The high selectivity of MECS-5a could be attributed to the sieving effects coming from the similar structures of MECS-5a and M’MOF series which have been reported possessing high selectivity of C2H2/C2H4. More importantly, we found that there are three small pore windows in MECS-5a, 4.5 × 5.3, 3.4 × 4.5, and 1.8 × 3.9 Å (Figure S5, Table S3). It is easier for the C2H2 to get inside the pores because of the smaller empirical kinetic diameters.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the C2H2 selectivity, the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) base method (c) was used to calculated the separation selectivity of C2H2 versus C2H4 in the binary C2H2/C2H4 mixtures containing 1% C2H2 to simulate the typical industrial mixture. As shown in c, the selectivity of C2H2/C2H4 displayed the decreasing trend from 17.5 to 12.6 in the range of 0-100 KPa. At 100 KPa and 298 K, the selectivity of compound MECS-5a is higher than most reported MOFs, such as the MOF-74 series, NOTT-300 (~5.5), and UTSA-100a (10.72), and similar to M'MOF-4a (14.4) (Table S3). The high selectivity of MECS-5a could be attributed to the sieving effects coming from the similar structures of MECS-5a and M'MOF series which have been reported possessing high selectivity of C2H2/C2H4. More importantly, we found that there are three small pore windows in MECS-5a, 4.5 × 5.3, 3.4 × 4.5, and 1.8 × 3.9 Å (Figure S5, Table S3). It is easier for the C2H2 to get inside the pores because of the smaller empirical kinetic diameters.

elements.content: The scatter diagram in shows the distribution diagram of the adsorption amount and the IAST calculation C2H2/C2H4 selectivity for MECS-5a and some reported typical MOFs. We can find that there only a few MOFs possess both high C2H2 uptake and high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, and most MOFs possess either high C2H2 uptake with low selectivity or high selectivity with low C2H2 uptake. Besides, the most reported MOFs featured with high C2H2 uptake but low selectivity while the MOFs with high selectivity are rare. Imitating from the M’MOF series, the pillar-layered MECS-5a not only inherits the high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity of the M’MOF series deriving from the sieving effects and pore space partition but also possesses moderate C2H2 uptake amount due to the expanding space in the 2D layer. All these factors contribute to the high C2H2 uptake and C2H2/C2H4 selectivity of MECS-5a.
elements.clean_text: The scatter diagram in  shows the distribution diagram of the adsorption amount and the IAST calculation C2H2/C2H4 selectivity for MECS-5a and some reported typical MOFs. We can find that there only a few MOFs possess both high C2H2 uptake and high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, and most MOFs possess either high C2H2 uptake with low selectivity or high selectivity with low C2H2 uptake. Besides, the most reported MOFs featured with high C2H2 uptake but low selectivity while the MOFs with high selectivity are rare. Imitating from the M'MOF series, the pillar-layered MECS-5a not only inherits the high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity of the M'MOF series deriving from the sieving effects and pore space partition but also possesses moderate C2H2 uptake amount due to the expanding space in the 2D layer. All these factors contribute to the high C2H2 uptake and C2H2/C2H4 selectivity of MECS-5a.

elements.content: To further test the performance of MECS-5a in the actual adsorption-based separation and purification processes, the powder of MECS-5a was packed in the column with the C2H2/C2H4 (1:99, v/v) mixture flowing over at 298 K. It is clear that MECS-5a could successfully separate the C2H2 from the feed gas (). The breakthrough points of C2H4 and C2H2 are 3.85 and 8.38 mmol/g, respectively, and the purity of C2H4 could successfully achieve >99.996% (Figure S10). What is more, the MECS-5a also presented good structural stability and regenerability as shown in Figures S7 and S10, which proves the possibility of MECS-5a for real industrial ethylene purification.
elements.clean_text: To further test the performance of MECS-5a in the actual adsorption-based separation and purification processes, the powder of MECS-5a was packed in the column with the C2H2/C2H4 (1:99, v/v) mixture flowing over at 298 K. It is clear that MECS-5a could successfully separate the C2H2 from the feed gas (). The breakthrough points of C2H4 and C2H2 are 3.85 and 8.38 mmol/g, respectively, and the purity of C2H4 could successfully achieve >99.996% (Figure S10). What is more, the MECS-5a also presented good structural stability and regenerability as shown in Figures S7 and S10, which proves the possibility of MECS-5a for real industrial ethylene purification.

elements.content: Column breakthrough experiment for C2H2/C2H4 (1:99, v/v) mixture at 298 K and 1 bar in MECS-5a.
elements.clean_text: 4  Column breakthrough experiment for C2H2/C2H4 (1:99, v/v) mixture at 298 K and 1 bar in MECS-5a.

elements.content: To better understand adsorption of MECS-5a for C2H2, the GCMC and DFT calculations were carried out to calculate the possible adsorption sites in MECS-5a. shows the specific spatial possibility distribution illustrating the tendency of particles after equilibrium. The distribution of acetylene is mostly in the round of the plane pore-partition group and the Cd3(O2CR)6 units in the 2D layer. It can be seen that there is a higher density distribution around the plane pore-partition group. This is because that the pore-partition group has unsaturated coordination Cd­(II) ions which can provide interaction sites for C2H2 (a). Besides, the hydrogen bond between the oxygen from the coordinated nitrate ion and the acetylene molecule associates with the π···π interaction between the acetylene molecule and the benzene ring of the ligand, providing the adsorption site for C2H2 as well (b). In the 2D layer of MECS-5a, the open-metal sites at the ends of Cd3(O2CR)6 units and the aromatic rings of the terephthalic acids provide the adsorption sites (c). From the distribution of C2H2 in MECS-5a, it is clear that the dinuclear plane pore-partition group plays an important role in the adsorption of C2H2. On the one hand, the planarity of the pore-partition group and the functional sites provide rich interaction sites for acetylene molecules. On the other hand, it subdivides the channel into more independent units and limits the acetylene molecules in the narrow space.
elements.clean_text: To better understand adsorption of MECS-5a for C2H2, the GCMC and DFT calculations were carried out to calculate the possible adsorption sites in MECS-5a.  shows the specific spatial possibility distribution illustrating the tendency of particles after equilibrium. The distribution of acetylene is mostly in the round of the plane pore-partition group and the Cd3(O2CR)6 units in the 2D layer. It can be seen that there is a higher density distribution around the plane pore-partition group. This is because that the pore-partition group has unsaturated coordination Cd(II) ions which can provide interaction sites for C2H2 (a). Besides, the hydrogen bond between the oxygen from the coordinated nitrate ion and the acetylene molecule associates with the π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the acetylene molecule and the benzene ring of the ligand, providing the adsorption site for C2H2 as well (b). In the 2D layer of MECS-5a, the open-metal sites at the ends of Cd3(O2CR)6 units and the aromatic rings of the terephthalic acids provide the adsorption sites (c). From the distribution of C2H2 in MECS-5a, it is clear that the dinuclear plane pore-partition group plays an important role in the adsorption of C2H2. On the one hand, the planarity of the pore-partition group and the functional sites provide rich interaction sites for acetylene molecules. On the other hand, it subdivides the channel into more independent units and limits the acetylene molecules in the narrow space.

elements.content: Possible binding sites of (a) unsaturated coordination Cd­(II) ions; (b) hydrogen bond and π···π interaction; (c) open-metal sites at the ends of Cd3(O2CR)6 units and the aromatic rings of the terephthalic acids for C2H2 in MECS-5a.
elements.clean_text: 6  Possible binding sites of (a) unsaturated coordination Cd(II) ions; (b) hydrogen bond and π⋅⋅⋅π interaction; (c) open-metal sites at the ends of Cd3(O2CR)6 units and the aromatic rings of the terephthalic acids for C2H2 in MECS-5a.

elements.content: In summary, to construct the MOFs with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and C2H2 capacity, by imitating from the M’MOF series with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, we report a pillar-layered MOF, MECS-5, which inherits the sieving effects of M’MOF to limit the adsorption of ethylene. It is interesting that the expanding space in the 2D layer compared to M’MOFs make it possible to capture more acetylene while the planar pore-partition group limits acetylene in the narrow space to ensure high selectivity and adsorption capacity at the same time. Obviously, this work not only successfully develops the potential separation materials for real industrial ethylene purification but also provides an example of designing MOFs with better separation performance based on the structure of reported MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, to construct the MOFs with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity and C2H2 capacity, by imitating from the M'MOF series with high C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, we report a pillar-layered MOF, MECS-5, which inherits the sieving effects of M'MOF to limit the adsorption of ethylene. It is interesting that the expanding space in the 2D layer compared to M'MOFs make it possible to capture more acetylene while the planar pore-partition group limits acetylene in the narrow space to ensure high selectivity and adsorption capacity at the same time. Obviously, this work not only successfully develops the potential separation materials for real industrial ethylene purification but also provides an example of designing MOFs with better separation performance based on the structure of reported MOFs.

cln_elements.content: Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (123.2 mg, 0.4 mmol), HMPCZ (54.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), and H2BDC (80.2 mg, 0.3 mmol) were dissolved in the mixture of dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a glass bottle with a cover and then heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, yellow block-shaped crystals of MECS-5 were obtained and washed with DMF. Yield: 46% (based on the ligand). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3451 (br), 2930 (m), 2859 (w), 1613 (w), 1574 (w), 1507 (m), 1469 (m), 1375 (m), 1315 (m), 1262 (m), 1181 (w), 1107 (s), 1081 (s), 982 (m), 826 (m), 771 (m), 739 (w), 620 (m), 458 (w).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Cd5(MPCZ)2(BDC)3(NO3)2(H2O)4]⋅G} n  (MECS-5)

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (123.2 mg, 0.4 mmol), HMPCZ (54.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), and H2BDC (80.2 mg, 0.3 mmol) were dissolved in the mixture of dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a glass bottle with a cover and then heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, yellow block-shaped crystals of MECS-5 were obtained and washed with DMF. Yield: 46% (based on the ligand). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3451 (br), 2930 (m), 2859 (w), 1613 (w), 1574 (w), 1507 (m), 1469 (m), 1375 (m), 1315 (m), 1262 (m), 1181 (w), 1107 (s), 1081 (s), 982 (m), 826 (m), 771 (m), 739 (w), 620 (m), 458 (w).

cln_elements.content:
To remove the solvents in MECS-5, the as-synthesized samples were immersed in MeOH for exchanging the solvent guest at least five times and then filtered. Then the samples were heated at 80 °C under vacuum conditions for 24 h to obtain the activated MECS-5a. The XRD and TGA results show that the solvent molecules were completely removed in the activated MECS-5a while maintaining the structure (). The N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K shows a typical type-I isotherm, indicating the microporosity of MECS-5a with the Langmuir area of MECS-5a calculated to be 964 m2 g–1 (a) which is larger than the M’MOF series, reflecting the expanding space of the MECS-5a.

As shown in b, the adsorption isotherms of C2H2 and C2H4 at 273 and 298 K indicate that compound MECS-5a has obviously different adsorption amounts for C2H2 and C2H4. The uptake amounts of MECS-5a for C2H2 are 125.5 cm3·g–1 (3.85 mmol·g–1) at 273 K and 1 bar and 86.2 cm3·g–1 (2.74 mmol·g–1) at 298 K and 1 bar. For C2H4, the uptake amounts are quite small, only 34.6 cm3·g–1 (1.54 mmol·g–1) at 273 K and 25.5 cm3·g–1 (1.14 mmol·g–1) at 298 K, respectively. Compared with the M’MOF series, the adsorption amount of MECS-5a for C2H2 is improved (Table S3), which could be attributed to the larger specific surface area coming from the expanding space in the 2D layer and the smaller segments divided by the dinuclear Cd­(II) plane pore-partition group. Though the C2H2 uptake amount of MECS-5a is smaller than the other MOFs, such as MOF-74 and NOTT-100a, the C2H4 uptake amount of MECS-5a is far smaller which reveals the better selectivity of MECS-5a.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Gas Separation Performance and Mechanism

To remove the solvents in MECS-5, the as-synthesized samples were immersed in MeOH for exchanging the solvent guest at least five times and then filtered. Then the samples were heated at 80 °C under vacuum conditions for 24 h to obtain the activated MECS-5a. The XRD and TGA results show that the solvent molecules were completely removed in the activated MECS-5a while maintaining the structure (). The N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K shows a typical type-I isotherm, indicating the microporosity of MECS-5a with the Langmuir area of MECS-5a calculated to be 964 m2 g-1 (a) which is larger than the M'MOF series, reflecting the expanding space of the MECS-5a.

As shown in b, the adsorption isotherms of C2H2 and C2H4 at 273 and 298 K indicate that compound MECS-5a has obviously different adsorption amounts for C2H2 and C2H4. The uptake amounts of MECS-5a for C2H2 are 125.5 cm3⋅g-1 (3.85 mmol⋅g-1) at 273 K and 1 bar and 86.2 cm3⋅g-1 (2.74 mmol⋅g-1) at 298 K and 1 bar. For C2H4, the uptake amounts are quite small, only 34.6 cm3⋅g-1 (1.54 mmol⋅g-1) at 273 K and 25.5 cm3⋅g-1 (1.14 mmol⋅g-1) at 298 K, respectively. Compared with the M'MOF series, the adsorption amount of MECS-5a for C2H2 is improved (Table S3), which could be attributed to the larger specific surface area coming from the expanding space in the 2D layer and the smaller segments divided by the dinuclear Cd(II) plane pore-partition group. Though the C2H2 uptake amount of MECS-5a is smaller than the other MOFs, such as MOF-74 and NOTT-100a, the C2H4 uptake amount of MECS-5a is far smaller which reveals the better selectivity of MECS-5a.

metadata.title:
Pillar-Layered
Metal–Organic Framework with Sieving Effect and Pore Space
Partition for Effective Separation of Mixed Gas C2H2/C2H4
